phrase.item: (There once) was a merchant.
From age seven to age seventy he was engaged in commerce.
Before age sixty, he had no children.
Misheard as "ʃaʃsolagi" (six years old)
One day, Hodja was sitting at home and thinking: "Oh Lord, my life is already coming to an end, (but) you've given me no children!

If tomorrow I should suddenly leave this world, then all my wealth will go to my distant relative." While he mused in this way, he received news that a son was born to him. ‎‎Hodja rejoiced, [and] praised god.
After Hodja's son was born, it seemed to him that he'd become young once more.
After that, Hodja once again loaded up his camels and mules and went off to trade.
He was engaged in commerce for another ten years.
When he turned seventy,
he no longer had the strength to travel all over the place.
One day he called his son to him and told him: "I'm no longer strong enough to work,
now all my hopes rest on you, you must master your father's trade!
You've got all these camels, all these mules, go ahead and load them up and journey forth with your neighbors!"
His son said: "O dear father, I'm not able to do commerce yet."
When his father hear these words, he said: "You just keep watch over the packs, and your neighbors will do the rest."
"Well, all right,"
said the son.
The next day they packed for the road,
and two days later that youth journeyed forth with his neighbors.
That youth had loaded goods on one hundred mules and one hundred camels.
They rode through several valleys and steppes, arrived at a place, but just as they wanted to dismount, [they saw] several people approaching with a dead man in a catafalque.
And there was such noise and such screaming!
One large young man [was] beating that dead man as he walk[ed].
When the merchant's son saw this, [he] asked: "Hey, young fellow, what sort of sin is on this dead man that you are carrying him and beating him?
[He has] departed into eternity, he ought to be buried here."
That young man said: "You don't know anything!
When he was alive, I lent him a whole lot of money.
But he did not repay his debt to me and died.
Now I'm going to go and drag his corpse from town to town."
The merchant's son asked him: "How much was his debt to you?"
The other man replied: "One camel with a pack."
The merchant's son immediately pointed out to him his own camel with the pack: "Over there lies a camel with a pack, go [and] take [it]!
But leave this young man, we will bury him here."
The other man let the dead man be, [and] went and took the camel with the pack. And the merchant's son buried him right there and went back home.
When he came through the door, his father saw [him] and said: "How come you're back so quickly, son?"
The son told him about what transpired and then added: "Now do what you will: drive me away or kill [me]!"
His father thought [about it] and said: "It's better not to have [any kind of] son than to have one like you.
Your neighbors are better than you.
They would have at the very least brought back most of the cargo [its' greater part], if not all of it.
From now on I'm dismissing you from all affairs." The son said: "Well, so be it."
By and by a year passed.
That youth behaved so pleasantly with his father that his father (finally) softened [towards him].
Again he permitted him to take up commerce.
And he told him then: "First and foremost, you need a servant, son,
and watch out that the servant doesn't turn out to be a bad one, if you're going to take a servant, then [he ought to be] a good one."
His son was surprised and asked his father: "So what kind of servant (is considered) good and what kind bad?"
His father answered: "A good servant is one who, wherever you might stay, will first and foremost make a bed for you, boil you some tea, and then settle in/stable your pack animals.
And in the morning he'll get up, load the animals, take and bring the horse to you, help you mount.
A bad servant, on the other hand, is one who'll give you back-talk.
And if you stop somewhere, that bad servant will say: 'If I must unload [the animals], then you go fetch the firewood.'"
The youth heard his father out and went off in search of a servant.
He rode out onto the road and ran into a handsome youth.
The youth told the merchant's son: "A pleasant journey [to you]! Where are you headed?"
The merchant's son told him: "I'm off to look for a servant."
The youth inquired: "In that case, won't you take me on as your servant?"
The merchant's son thought a little and said: "All right."
They both returned, [and] went to the merchant Hodja.
His son said: "O father, I found myself a servant."
Hodja said: "Very good, if that is so then start packing for the road and be off!"
The youth loaded up forty mules, forty camels, asked for his father's blessing, and was on his way.

After they passed several valleys and steppes, they made it to a barren place. The sun has already concealed itself behind the mountain-tops. The servant quickly unloaded the packs and before doing anything else made a bed for the merchant's son. After that he prepared him tea. After tea he settled in the pack animals, [then] took a rope, [and] went to the forest for firewood.
[He] brought some firewood, started cooking food.
Made the food, and just as he was about to carry it to the merchant's son, a dog ran through [lit. into] the tent door.
The merchant's son saw the dog and brightened up a lot: "In Mysati valley we had no dog with us.
Nice that one/it came now of its own accord."
The servant expressed disapproval, said: "No, we don't need this dog!"
Hodja's son repeated again: "No, a dog is good for us."
The servant saw that the merchant's son was very displeased, said nothing, [and] sat down quietly.
When they began to eat the food,
the dog was also given [some] in a separate bowl. ‎‎They ate [and] lay down to sleep. The dog looked - they were asleep.
Then she quietly got up and ran off.
In the morning, the servant rose from his bed, [and] saw there was no dog.
He said to Hodja's son: "That dog that we took in and petted yesterday, she ran off."
Afterwards they ate, loaded up the pack animals.
Until the evening they were on the road.
When they grew tired, they stopped again in the Mysati valley by the time of namaz. [Namaz is the name for the sunset Muslim prayer.]
The servant took off all the packs, made a bed for the merchant's son, made him tea, and right away took a rope and went to get firewood.
​He brought firewood, settled in the pack animals, [and] started making food.
When the food was ready, he wanted to put it into a bowl, when the same dog ran through the door again.
The merchant's son rejoiced: "Our dog came!"
The servant said nothing.
Then she was given a lot of food.
[Everyone] ate and went to sleep.
The servant looked - the merchant's son had fallen asleep.
He carefully drew [his] sword from its scabbard, started watching the dog.
After a while, the dog quietly got up and ran off.
The servant [went] after her.
They ran for a long time, [and finally they] ran into the Toriksalot gorge, where if you scream, there's no sound.
They ran closer to the gorge, and [there] he saw a mud hut of some kind. That dog ran around the mud hut and disappeared.
The servant looked and looked, [but] there was no entrance into it from any side.
Then, climbing, he went up on the roof.
There was a small opening in the roof.
He looked through this opening, and [saw that] there were three fairies sitting in the house. [parizod/fairies are considered nice and feminine]
One [sat] by the hearth, another - on the smaller plank bed/pallet, the third - on the lower plank bed/pallet.
All three sat in silence.
After a while, the fairy that was by the hearth said: "O God, what a stupid merchant's son:
An almasti [supernatural beings with a dark energy- generally male but in this case female] turns into a person, comes over [and] eats his bread!"
Another fairy, the one on the smaller plank bed/pallet, said: "She will eventually give him some trouble, [and] if she manages it, [she'll] kill him."

The third fairy, the one on the lower plank bed/pallet, said: "If she kills him, takes a bit of his meat, and makes a remedy against all ailments [from it], that would be very good, there would be a medicine from any ailment."
The servant heard them all out and left.
Day broke, and he made it [back] to the tent.
The merchant's son said: "Where were you?"
He answered: "A camel got itself untied, I chased it down and brought it [back]."
Then they once more loaded the animals and were on their way.
Once more they were on the road until the evening. Near the town, on a sandy place, they pitched [their] tent and stopped [there].
Once they had done everything that was necessary [and begun to eat], the same dog showed up again.
This time around, the merchant's son got angry at her.
But the servant still sat there quietly. They ate [and] went to bed.
The servant began to observe the dog.
When they fell asleep, the dog carefully rose and ran out.
Right away, the servant bared his sword under his fur coat and ran out after her.
They ran for a short while, and [then] he caught her.
Immediately, he tossed the fur coat over her head and ran [her] through with the sword. She broke apart into two pieces.
Then, out of all her parts, he made something like a remedy and named the ailment [it was meant to treat].
From all that, he made a ball/lump, tied it up in a kerchief, and quickly returned.
He arrived, [and] the merchant's son once again asked him: "Where were you?"
The other man said: "The mules got themselves untied, I brought them back."
They loaded the animals and started traveling on the road.
At high noon, they entered the town.
Right then they [suddenly] heard a loud voice.
It was the voice of the king's herald/crier.
He said: "The king's daughter is very ill.
Any healer, any one at all, let them come as quickly as possible to the king's chambers.
If it should happen that he heals the king's daughter, then the king will give his daughter to him."
The servant heard this, came up to the merchant's son,
[and] asked him:
"Today the king's herald announced that the king's daughter is very ill, [and] the girl will be given to whoever heals her.
What if you give me permission to go heal her?"
The merchant's son became indignant: "If I, a reasonably literate [man], am not going, then you are apparently quite stupid, given that you know nothing and are making plans to go to the king.
How are you not getting this? The king's court has so many learned men, so many doctors, they all can't heal her, but you, a nobody, what would you know about it?"
The servant thought for a long time, then asked his permission again. The merchant's son said: "Well, all right, go."
The servant went, made it to the palace gates [lit. king's gates], asked permission from the guards: "I'm a healer, [I] came to heal the king's daughter."
The guards joyfully relayed to the king that a healer has turned up.
The healer was led to the king.
The king saw him and said: "If you heal my daughter, then let only her name remain for me, the rest [will go] to you."
The servant agreed and went to the girl.

First he examined her, then he understood her malady. She turned out to have an internal disease. He took some medicine from his medicine [pouch] and put it into a piala. [piala is a small ceramic bowl used around Central Asia]
Then he gave [it] to the girl.
As soon as the girl drank [it], right then she vomited.
Again, the servant gave her the medicine for the second time.
When she drank the medicine this time, a bit of blood came out from inside her.
The girl lost consciousness.
She lay unconscious for a long time, and finally came around.
The servant asked her: "How do you feel?"
The girl said: "Very well, I'm cured now, I shall go to my father!"
The servant said: "No, tomorrow we shall go together!"
Morning came, and they both went to the king. When the king saw his daughter, he became very very happy.
And then [he] said to his daughter: "Now you are no longer mine, I promised [you to him], now you belong to this man here."
The servant addressed the king with a request: "She is my sister, and here I have a brother with me, [may] I give her to him?" [referring to the merchant's son]
The king agreed.
The servant conferred with the merchant's son, they sold all the cargo they had with them, [and] began to arrange the wedding.
They held a feast all day and all night.
After that the merchant's son took his wife and returned home.
And when he along with his servant came home, they held a feast again.
Then the servant said amiably to the merchant's son: "My service is now over, what do you think?"
The merchant's son said: "As you wish, let us divide the riches we brought back from [our] journey." The servant said: "All right."
They divided the riches equally.
The servant [then] treated [his friend's] wife one more time.
He healed her completely, so that she had no trace of malady left.
And then the servant declared to the merchant's son: "I have no use for these riches, take them [for yourself]!
You see, I was that very dead man whom you traded in that valley for a camel with a pack, you freed me from a tyrant and buried [me].
With that, my life is over, all the best!"
He said goodbye and left.
And the merchant's son with his wife lived in happiness and prosperity.
